[p][b]Gait alteration[/b] is a change in the manner that a person walks and generally moves about throughout their environment. Depending on the substance, this can often be described as walking in a "robotic", "mechanical", or "zombie-like" manner that although unusual in appearance, does not necessarily impede the person's ability to exert coordination or fine motor control.[/p]

[p]Gait alteration is often accompanied by other coinciding effects such as [int-link to="/effects/motor-control-loss"]motor control loss[/int-link] and [int-link to="/effects/sedation"]sedation[/int-link]. It is most commonly induced under the influence of moderate dosages of [int-link to="/summaries/dissociatives"]dissociatives[/int-link] such as ketamine, and especially [int-link to="/substances/dxm/"]DXM[/int-link].[ref to="1" /] However, it may also occur to a lesser extent under the influence of other compounds such as depressants, [int-link to="/summaries/psychedelics/miscellaneous"]psychedelics[/int-link] and [int-link to="/summaries/deliriants"]deliriants[/int-link].[/p]
